articles.headline: Home for Sale, by Anxious Owner
articles.snippet: Many home sellers are offering thousands of dollars in incentives so they do not have to slice deeply into asking prices.
articles.abstract: Many home sellers are offering thousands of dollars in incentives so they do not have to slice deeply into asking prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Home sales are falling rapidly, and the number of houses on the market is surging. Yet each new economic report offering evidence of a housing slowdown also shows that the national median home price has continued to rise over the last year.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and David Leonhardt

articles.headline: Beating of Lawyer Threatens Hong Kong’s Allure
articles.snippet: An assault on prominent lawyer Albert Ho threatens to damage Hong Kong’s reputation for the fair settlement of disputes in court.
articles.abstract: An assault on prominent lawyer Albert Ho threatens to damage Hong Kong’s reputation for the fair settlement of disputes in court.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Aug. 24  The anonymous letter arrived Thursday evening with a box-cutter blade.

articles.headline: Apple Joins in a Recall of Batteries
articles.snippet: Apple Computer said it was recalling 1.8 million laptop batteries because they could overheat and catch fire.
articles.abstract: Apple Computer said it was recalling 1.8 million laptop batteries because they could overheat and catch fire.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 — Apple Computer said Thursday that it was recalling 1.8 million batteries from some models of its laptop computers because of a risk that they could overheat and catch fire.

articles.headline: Next-Day Pill No Pot of Gold for Its Maker
articles.snippet: The political debate over Plan B may have helped raise the profile of its maker, Barr Pharmaceuticals, but over-the-counter sales will barely register on its balance sheet.
articles.abstract: The political debate over Plan B may have helped raise the profile of its maker, Barr Pharmaceuticals, but over-the-counter sales will barely register on its balance sheet.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a business opportunity for Barr Pharmaceuticals, Plan B is not even Plan C.

articles.abstract: An examination of the case file shows that there is a body of evidence to support the prosecutor’s decision to take the matter to a jury.

articles.headline: China Gives Times Researcher 3 Years
articles.snippet: China dismissed a state-secrets charge against Zhao Yan, but sentenced him on a lesser charge.
articles.abstract: China dismissed a state-secrets charge against Zhao Yan, but sentenced him on a lesser charge.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING, Friday, Aug. 25 — A Beijing court on Friday morning unexpectedly dismissed a state secrets charge against a researcher for The New York Times but sentenced him to three years in prison on a lesser, unrelated charge of fraud.
articles.byline: By Jim Yardley and Joseph Kahn

articles.headline: If Your Stocks Fall, Demand a Refund
articles.snippet: Overstock.com chief executive Patrick M. Byrne’s latest legal theory would allow those who bought the company’s stock before it plunged to get their money back from their brokers.
articles.abstract: Overstock.com chief executive Patrick M. Byrne’s latest legal theory would allow those who bought the company’s stock before it plunged to get their money back from their brokers.
articles.lead_paragraph: AS a legal innovator, Patrick M. Byrne deserves a place in a hall of fame. He has invented causes of action that no one else had dreamed up, and gotten them taken seriously by courts.

articles.headline: If Your Stocks Fall, Demand a Refund
articles.snippet: AS a legal innovator, Patrick M. Byrne deserves a place in a hall of fame. He has invented causes of action that no one else had dreamed up, and gotten them taken seriously by courts.     Mr. Byrne persuaded a state to pass a law that stunned Wall...
articles.abstract: AS a legal innovator, Patrick M. Byrne deserves a place in a hall of fame. He has invented causes of action that no one else had dreamed up, and gotten them taken seriously by courts.     Mr. Byrne persuaded a state to pass a law that stunned Wall Street, and got the Securities and Exchange Commission to investigate his enemies.
articles.lead_paragraph: AS a legal innovator, Patrick M. Byrne deserves a place in a hall of fame. He has invented causes of action that no one else had dreamed up, and gotten them taken seriously by courts.

articles.headline: It's Never Too Early (Even in '06) To Gear Up for Presidential Race
articles.snippet: For Chuck Larson, a former chairman of the Iowa Republican Party, the past few months have included a flight to Albany for dinner at the executive mansion with Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, a likely 2008 presidential contender. Mr. Larson was...
articles.abstract: For Chuck Larson, a former chairman of the Iowa Republican Party, the past few months have included a flight to Albany for dinner at the executive mansion with Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, a likely 2008 presidential contender. Mr. Larson was also summoned for a long private sit-down with Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts at a hotel in Des Moines.     And there was an hourlong visit with Senator John McCain of Arizona at his private office on Capitol Hill, where Mr. McCain, a Vietnam veteran, asked Mr. Larson about his just-completed tour in Iraq. That one closed the deal. So last week, Mr. Larson could be found at Mr. McCain's side at the Iowa State Fair, squiring the senator from cow to hog to the pork-chop-on-a-stick stand in his new role as Mr. McCain's Iowa adviser.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Aug. 24 - For Chuck Larson, a former chairman of the Iowa Republican Party, the past few months have included a flight to Albany for dinner at the executive mansion with Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, a likely 2008 presidential contender. Mr. Larson was also summoned for a long private sit-down with Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts at a hotel in Des Moines.

articles.headline: Inquiry Opened Into Israeli Use of U.S. Bombs
articles.snippet: The State Department is investigating whether Israel's use of American-made cluster bombs in southern Lebanon violated secret agreements with the United States that restrict when it can employ such weapons, two officials said.     The investigatio...
articles.abstract: The State Department is investigating whether Israel's use of American-made cluster bombs in southern Lebanon violated secret agreements with the United States that restrict when it can employ such weapons, two officials said.     The investigation by the department's Office of Defense Trade Controls began this week, after reports that three types of American cluster munitions, anti-personnel weapons that spray bomblets over a wide area, have been found in many areas of southern Lebanon and were responsible for civilian casualties.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: Home for Sale, by Anxious Owner
articles.snippet: Home sales are falling rapidly, and the number of houses on the market is surging. Yet each new economic report offering evidence of a housing slowdown also shows that the national median home price has continued to rise over the last year.      T...
articles.abstract: Home sales are falling rapidly, and the number of houses on the market is surging. Yet each new economic report offering evidence of a housing slowdown also shows that the national median home price has continued to rise over the last year.      To understand how this could be happening, consider a three-bedroom house surrounded by oak and redwood trees, not far from the Golden Gate Bridge, in San Rafael, Calif. Reluctant to cut the price from its current listing of $1.54 million, its owners are instead offering a weeklong vacation time-share, every year for life, worth about $10,000, or an equal amount toward lease of a car.
articles.lead_paragraph: Home sales are falling rapidly, and the number of houses on the market is surging. Yet each new economic report offering evidence of a housing slowdown also shows that the national median home price has continued to rise over the last year.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and David Leonhardt

articles.headline: New Orleans Shops Struggle to Survive
articles.snippet: For all the cheerful displays of Louisiana's best-known hot sauce and all the pepper-shaped and pepper-flavored products on the shelves, the Tabasco Country Store is in deep trouble.     The shop, at the airport, was closed for months after Hurric...
articles.abstract: For all the cheerful displays of Louisiana's best-known hot sauce and all the pepper-shaped and pepper-flavored products on the shelves, the Tabasco Country Store is in deep trouble.     The shop, at the airport, was closed for months after Hurricane Katrina, and sales remain down 45 percent. The owner, Laura Y. Drumm, has mortgaged her house to the hilt; she has borrowed from her in-laws; her insurance will not pay for her losses, and neither will the government. Her one employee did not return after the storm, and her husband, Hughes, is running the store's cash register seven days a week.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: Apple Joins in a Recall of Batteries
articles.snippet: Apple Computer said Thursday that it was recalling 1.8 million batteries from some models of its laptop computers because of a risk that they could overheat and catch fire.     The batteries were made by a unit of Sony, which also made the 4.1 mil...
articles.abstract: Apple Computer said Thursday that it was recalling 1.8 million batteries from some models of its laptop computers because of a risk that they could overheat and catch fire.     The batteries were made by a unit of Sony, which also made the 4.1 million laptop batteries that Dell recalled last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 - Apple Computer said Thursday that it was recalling 1.8 million batteries from some models of its laptop computers because of a risk that they could overheat and catch fire.

articles.headline: F.D.A. Approves Broader Access to Next-Day Pill
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved over-the-counter sales of the morning-after contraceptive pill to women 18 and older, resolving one of the most contentious issues in the agency's 100-year history.     Nationwide over-the-coun...
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved over-the-counter sales of the morning-after contraceptive pill to women 18 and older, resolving one of the most contentious issues in the agency's 100-year history.     Nationwide over-the-counter sales of the drug, Plan B, are expected to start by the end of the year. It will be sold in pharmacies and health clinics only, and buyers must show proof of age. Anyone under age 18 will still need a prescription. Men may also buy Plan B for a partner.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 - The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved over-the-counter sales of the morning-after contraceptive pill to women 18 and older, resolving one of the most contentious issues in the agency's 100-year history.

articles.headline: Next-Day Pill No Pot of Gold for Its Maker
articles.snippet: As a business opportunity for Barr Pharmaceuticals, Plan B is not even Plan C.     That was the view of drug industry analysts yesterday after the Food and Drug Administration approved sales of Barr's Plan B emergency contraceptive pill without a ...
articles.abstract: As a business opportunity for Barr Pharmaceuticals, Plan B is not even Plan C.     That was the view of drug industry analysts yesterday after the Food and Drug Administration approved sales of Barr's Plan B emergency contraceptive pill without a prescription to people 18 or older.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a business opportunity for Barr Pharmaceuticals, Plan B is not even Plan C.

articles.headline: China Gives Times Researcher 3 Years
articles.snippet: A Beijing court on Friday morning unexpectedly dismissed a state secrets charge against a researcher for The New York Times but sentenced him to three years in prison on a lesser, unrelated charge of fraud.     The verdict against the researcher, ...
articles.abstract: A Beijing court on Friday morning unexpectedly dismissed a state secrets charge against a researcher for The New York Times but sentenced him to three years in prison on a lesser, unrelated charge of fraud.     The verdict against the researcher, Zhao Yan, 44, spared him a prison sentence of 10 years or longer and also served as a blunt rebuke to the investigation by state security agents. Agents began detaining Mr. Zhao almost two years ago and accused him of leaking state secrets to The Times. He has consistently stated that he is innocent of both charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING, Friday, Aug. 25 - A Beijing court on Friday morning unexpectedly dismissed a state secrets charge against a researcher for The New York Times but sentenced him to three years in prison on a lesser, unrelated charge of fraud.
articles.byline: By Jim Yardley and Joseph Kahn

articles.headline: Beating of Lawyer Threatens Hong Kong’s Allure
articles.snippet: The anonymous letter arrived Thursday evening with a box-cutter blade.     It was addressed to one of the city's best-known lawmakers and litigators. And it held a chilling reminder of his beating at a McDonald's restaurant on Sunday.
articles.abstract: The anonymous letter arrived Thursday evening with a box-cutter blade.     It was addressed to one of the city's best-known lawmakers and litigators. And it held a chilling reminder of his beating at a McDonald's restaurant on Sunday.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Aug. 24 - The anonymous letter arrived Thursday evening with a box-cutter blade.

articles.headline: Files From Duke Rape Case Give Details but No Answers
articles.snippet: On March 21, a week after an African-American woman charged that she had been raped by three white Duke University lacrosse players, the police sergeant supervising the investigation met with the sexual-assault nurse who had examined the woman in ...
articles.abstract: On March 21, a week after an African-American woman charged that she had been raped by three white Duke University lacrosse players, the police sergeant supervising the investigation met with the sexual-assault nurse who had examined the woman in the emergency room. The sergeant, Mark D. Gottlieb, reviewed the medical report, which did not say much: some swelling, no visible bruises.      But the sergeant's case notes also recount what the nurse told him in response to his questions: that the woman appeared to be in so much pain that it took ''an extended period of time'' to examine her, and that the ''blunt force trauma'' seen in the examination ''was consistent with the sexual assault that was alleged by the victim.''
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
articles.byline: By Duff Wilson and Jonathan D. Glater
